Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CSUMS: URGE to Compute
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ringland
DMS-0802994
Carbonara
DMS-0802964

URGE to Compute provides a year-long computationally
intensive Undergraduate Research Group Experience in the
mathematical sciences to an annual cohort of 12 undergraduate
mathematics majors. A collaboration of the University at Buffalo
(UB), Buffalo State College (BSC), and the Hauptman-Woodward
Medical Research Institute, the project brings together an
interdisciplinary group of 16 faculty researchers who have a
shared sense of the importance of computation in the mathematical
sciences, a record of successful supervision of undergraduate
research, and a commitment to increasing the effectiveness of the
preparation of students at UB and BSC for post-graduate education
and careers in the many fields that now demand a combination of
computational and mathematical skills. Prior to commencing the
full-year research experience, students take calculus,
differential equations, linear algebra, and a new sophomore
course in scientific and mathematical computing which was
developed with this project in mind and is offered to all math
majors. Special efforts are made to recruit minorities and
women, who are underrepresented in the mathematical sciences.
The year of research begins in the Spring semester of the
students' junior year with: a support course that provides
background on the theme that unifies all the research projects
for that year (e.g. stochastic processes in 2009); a team-taught
course on the tools and methods of computational research;
regular meetings with the research project mentor; and the first
part of a seminar that runs throughout the year. Research
continues through the summer, and students write an honors thesis
or a paper for publication in the Fall. Computational resources
available to the students include a 2000-node cluster and a
visualization laboratory at UB's Center for Computational
Research. Talks by eminent outside researchers are a feature of
the seminar, and students attend a national conference in an area
related to their research, disseminate their results at regional
meetings and local exhibitions of undergraduate scholarship, and
participate in outreach activities at local high schools. After
the year is over, in their final undergraduate semester, the now
highly trained students serve as teaching assistants in the
introductory differential equations course that is taken by all
mathematics, engineering, and science students.

Over the multi-year course of the project, the research
focuses on a wide variety of topics of societal importance.
These include optical fiber communications, agricultural pest
control, cryptography, medical imaging, and the behavior of
materials (from semiconductor devices to mudflows). The project
not only trains a select annual cohort in these vital areas, but
also reaches a substantial fraction of all math majors at UB and
BSC with a curriculum that is computationally enriched by the
preparation and support courses for the project, and a
departmental life that is enhanced by the seminars and the
exposure to peers engaged in research. The project is supported
by the MPS Division of Mathematical Sciences, the MPS Office of
Multidisciplinary Activities, and the EHR Division of
Undergraduate Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project "URGE to Compute" (Undergradate Research Group Experiences in Computational Mathematics) was to boost national competitiveness and accelerate technological development by bringing the strengths of mathematically talented students into the realm of research in computational applied math, science and engineering. Students from diverse socio-economic backgrounds were specifically encouraged by the collaboration between an AAU research institution (SUNY University at Buffalo) and an urban 4-year college (SUNY Buffalo State).

The goal was accomplished through providing training and intense research experiences for undergraduate mathematics majors in research projects that had the following qualities: (i) they were computational in nature, (ii) they were of longer duration (a full calendar year) than traditional research experiences for undergraduates, and (iii) the work was conducted in a large continuously interacting cohort, around 12 students each year, providing sustained opportunities for peer-support and role modeling. Unifying each year's projects with a common theme, and starting each cohort in January, allowed us to use the Spring semester for training of the students both in underlying mathematics and science needed for their specific research projects, and in the tools and methods of computational research in general, including communication tools and skills. The students were then well prepared for the full-time intensive 8-week Summer session when the bulk of the research work was conducted. The Fall semester was then available for preparing talks and visual presentations of their results. Additional essential features of the project included its interdisciplinary nature - engaging faculty mentors in six disciplines: Biochemistry, Chemistry, Computer Science, Earth Science, Mathematics and Physics - and the large number of faculty - 21 over the 6 years - who teamed up to provide challenging, coherent and supportive experiences for the 69 students who participated. 

Of the 69 participating students, 26% were female, 2 were African-American and 1 was Hispanic. 64 students (93%) completed the year-long experience, and 60% of those entered graduate programs in Mathematics, Physics, Computer Science, and Engineering, including PhD programs at Arizona, UC Berkeley, Brown, Columbia, Courant, Purdue, UCLA, Waterloo. Another 20% of the students moved directly into industry as software developers and engineers, including 2 at Google and 1 at Twitter. 6% entered the teaching profession, and the remainder entered professional programs or employment in other fields including law, accounting, and actuarial science. Two of our students received prestigious NSF graduate fellowships, and one was first place winner in the 2015 grand finals of the Association for Computing Machinery Student Research Competition. Almost every student presented the results of his or her research at a national or regional meeting, and 15 publications in refereed research journals have so far resulted from their work.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in the quality of the training provided to the students, who are now either amplifying the expertise gained in this project in gradute programs or are already applying it in the workforce, and in the advancement of knowledge represented by the publications that resulted from the research the students conducted in the project. More than half of the students who completed the program published their work in professional peer-reviewed journals or conference proceedings.
